a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original document is in the public domain. Subject to certain exceptions, public domain works may be freely copied or used in the creation of derivative works without permission, or authorization, of the former copyright owners.

The text encoding was created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and is governed by a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

note.p: This proof is grouped with other copies of proof sheets that represent different stages of the printing. Whitman has also written instructions to the printer on this proof sheet. "Of That Blithe Throat of Thine" was published first in January, 1885.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: Of That Blithe Throat of Thine
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839&1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
The verso contains another proof of "Of That Blithe Throat of Thine" which has been crossed-out by Whitman's hand.

lg.note:
correct carefully—then take
50 impressions on paper like this.
(so asto write on) ab't this size—
— ☞ 20 as here, with the name— then
take out the name, (Walt Whitman)
& print the other 30—
—(try to give me good impressions
a good clear job)

head.hi: Of that Blithe Throat of Thine

lg.note:
[More than 83 degrees north—about a good days''s/ steaming distance to the Pole
by one of our fast oceaners in clear water—Greely heard the song of a single
snow-bird merrily sounding over the desolation.]
lg.l: Of that blithe throat of thine from arctic bleak and blank,

I'll mind the lesson, solitary bird—let me too welcome chilling
drifts

E'ven the profoundest chill, as now—a torpid pulse, a brain un–
nerv'dunnerv'd,
Old age land-lock'd within its winter bay—(cold, cold, O cold!)
These snowy hairs, my feeble arm, my frozen feet,
For them thy faith ‸,/ thy rule I take, and grave it to the last;

Not summer's zones alone—not chants of youth ‸,/ or south's warm
tides along,

But held by sluggish floes, pack'd in the northern ice, the cumulus
of years,
These with gay heart I also sing.
